and magnesium salts of phosphomolybdic acid, H3PMo12040 Jean-Michel Tatibou~t a,*, Christelle Montalescot a, Katharina Briickman b a Laboratoire de Catalyse en Chimie Organique, URA CNRS 350, Universit~ de Poitiers, 40, avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86022, Poitiers cedex, France b Institute of Catalysis and Surface Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, ul. Niejapominacek, 30239-Krakow, Poland Received 17 November 1995; revised 27 November 1995; accepted 27 November 1995 Abstract Calcium and magnesium salts of phosphomolybdic acid H3PMo~20~ were formed in situ during catalyst preparation by impregnation, by a reaction between Ca and Mg species previously deposited on the surface of the silica support and an aqueous solution of H3PMol2040. This two-step procedure could constitute a general and convenient way to prepare supported het- eropolyacid salt catalysts. Keywords: Heteropoly acids; Phosphomolybdic acid; Silica I. Introduction Heteropolyoxometalate compounds with a Keggin structure like phospho- molybdic acid (H3PMol204o), are characterized by a strong Br0nsted acidity which can limit their use in mild oxidation reactions [1]. This acidity can be controlled or limited by salt formation [1-4]. It has also been shown that the salt forms of HPA are more stable than the acidic forms [1,2,5,6]. Moreover, salts " Corresponding author. 0926-860X/96/$15.00 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDI 0926-860X(95)003 1 0-X L2 J.-M. Tatibou~t et al./ Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) L1-L6 have a lower water solubility than the acid forms [1,7], limiting the possibility to use the salt form directly for the preparation of supported catalysts by impregna- tion. In addition, hydrolysis of the salt can occur during the impregnation procedure, leading to the presence at the surface of the support of different species whose composition varies from the acidic to the fully salted form of the HPA. To rule out these difficulties, we have investigated the possibility to form the required salt in situ, directly on the support surface, from the acidic form of H3PMo ~2040 and previously supported cations. 2. Catalyst preparation In order to avoid the formation of several species corresponding to different stages of salt formation we have used a divalent cation (Ca2or Mg2 which can lead only to the formation of the partial salt of phosphomolybdic acid HXPMol204o with X = Ca or Mg. The cation was previously deposited on the silica support surface (Rh6ne- Poulenc, XOA 400, BET surface area--400 m2/g) by impregnation with a slight excess of solvent, from an aqueous solution of the corresponding nitrate. After drying overnight at 120, the samples were calcined in air for 2 h at 500. The Keggin anion was brought on by impregnation with a slight excess of solvent, from an aqueous solution of phosphomolybdic acid, followed by drying at 100 for 2 h and overnight at 120. The concentration and the volume of the impregnating solutions were adjusted to ensure a divalent cation-Keggin anion ratio of 1. The amount of cation previously deposited on the silica surface was calculated to obtain a final surface coverage of 0.3 (Mo = 12.7 wt.-%) or 0.5 (Mo = 18.6 wt.-%) monolayer (mnl) by assuming that they are fully dispersed on the silica surface and that each cation is able to react with phosphomolybdic acid to form a HXPMo1204o species occupying a surface area of 144 ,~2 [8]. Blank samples were prepared by the same procedure, the first step being performed with only pure water. The second step (HPA impregna- tion) was performed either as in the catalyst preparation (impregnation with an aqueous solution of H3PMot204o) or by impregnation with an aqueous solution of the HMgPMo12040 salt. The BET surface areas of both samples measured after degassing at 250 under vacuum do not show significant variations from the value of the silica support. The preparation procedures and the nomenclature of the samples are summarized in Table 1. 3. Results and discussion Characterization of our catalysts was performed by differential thermal analysis (DTA), infrared spectroscopy and by the catalytic test reaction of methanol oxidation. J.-M. They exhibit, for all the samples, in addition to the bands of silica at 1100 and 800 cm-l, the main bands of the Keggin units [9] at 1065 cm-I (vas P-O), 978 cm-l (visible as a shoulder) and 960 cm- l (Vas Mo = Or), and 874 cm- t (v~ Mo_Ob_Mo), showing that the Keggin structure is preserved after catalyst preparation. Tatibou~t et aL /Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) L1-L6 L5 Catalytic methanol oxidation, a structure sensitive reaction, can be used to characterize the acid-base character of a catalyst [10-13]. It has been shown that dimethyl ether is formed by a dehydration reaction between two molecules of methanol on acid sites, whereas the mild oxidation products [CH20, HCOOCH3, (CH30)2CH2] require redox sites [12,14]. In first approximation, the higher the dimethyl ether selectivity, the stronger the acidity of the catalyst. From our results, it appears that the presence of the divalent cations Ca or Mg on the silica surface decreases the dimethyl ether selectivity, and then indicates a decrease in the surface acidity. Moreover, the nature of the divalent cation seems to play a minor role in selectivities which are very close for the samples containing Mg or Ca. This behaviour could be due to salt formation which decreases the amount of acidic protons able to perform dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether. This hypothesis is confirmed by the two main results of thermal analysis studies: the presence of Mg or Ca deeply modifies the thermograms, revealing an interaction between these cations and phosphomolybdic acid; the quite identical thermograms of MgPMo/SiO2 and HPMo/Mg-SiO2 samples suggest that the same species are present on the silica surface whatever the preparation procedure. We can therefore propose that during the impregnation-drying procedure of H3PMo~204o a strong interaction occurs between Mg or Ca species present on the silica surface and the Keggin anion, probably by reaction between the basic hydroxy groups bonded to Mg or Ca and the acidic protons of H3PMo~204o, leading to the formation of a HXPMol2040 (X = Ca or Mg) surface salt. The quite identical catalytic behaviour of the two Mg containing samples indicates that most of the H3PMot2040 has reacted with the Mg cations to form the HMgPMo~204o salt. This observation implies: (i) the Mg cations were previ- ously highly, dispersed on the silica surface, the mean diameter of the Keggin unit ( = 12 A) being almost two orders of magnitude larger than those of a Mg cation (0.132 ,~) [15]; (ii) as all the Keggin units are in close contact with the silica surface, they are in the form of a monolayer deposit. The similar catalytic results observed with the HPMo/Ca-SiO2 sample suggest that the same situation occurs for the Ca cations. The resulting catalytically active phase supported on silica appears then to be grafted on the silica surface through the divalent cations which are in strong interaction both with Keggin units and the silica surface, constituting a 'chemical glue' [ 16] able to anchor the Keggin units on the silica surface. 4. Conclusion It appears from these results that it is possible to form in situ, on the surface support, the salt of an heteropolyacid and a previously supported cation. This L6 J.-M. Tatibou~t et al./ Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) L1-L6 reaction can occur during the catalyst preparation by a two-step procedure. These results seems to be able to be generalized to various cations and heteropolyacids and could constitute a new and original way to prepare sup- ported heteropolyacid salt catalysts or multicomponent supported oxides after thermal decomposition of the heteropoly compound species.
